TopicTitle: Video Wednesday: The end of Scott's Interstellar Quest

Articles.Content: This has to be one of the longest series in KSP and this week it came to an end: Scott Manley’s Interstellar Quest. Over the course of a year and three months, in 105 videos, his Kerbals have explored the solar system in a quest to gather the knowledge to build an Interstellar drive. The moment they succeed they’re forced to leave their home planet for good. Where one door closes another one will open, as you will see in the video!

Welp, it's finally over. ![;.;](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cry.gif)

Tbh I stopped watching after episode 70, because it stopped interesting me. I did watch this episode and it was quite good, so I hope Scott will finally start a new modded series.

The one series I watched from start to finish on youtube. I really enjoyed the series and I look forward to a possible RSS series from him in the near future. Thanks for your time and dedication Scott!

> 
> The one series I watched from start to finish on youtube. I really enjoyed the series and I look forward to a possible RSS series from him in the near future. Thanks for your time and dedication Scott!

Same here. I still remember the day I watched the first episode. Oh well ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif). I'm excited for his new series.
I wonder if Scott Manley is going to level-up to RSS for the next series?

Good series, but I'm glad to see it end. I've done long-running series before and i know how hard heavily modded games get to play after a while. I bet his 20-minute episodes were taking HOURS if not DAYS to just PLAY - little alone edit - by the end there.
I'm in the midst of watching it, actually... I'm in the middle of episode seven I think. XD

Very very enjoyable series. I'm glad I was convinced early on to pare back my mod collection as Scott had to suffer through quite a lot of issues, not least of which was the NaN corruption problem and those... long... burns.

> 
> I wonder if Scott Manley is going to level-up to RSS for the next series?

He mentioned it as an explicit possibility a while back in one of the Interstellar videos. Given that and the highly suggestive ending to the Interstellar Quest series, I'd say it's likely.

And I'm stoked.
Ah one chapter closes, another opens! Would love to see a RSS Manley Quest

I started playing when .23 came out, at the encouragement of a new coworker. Googling KSP, I eventually found this series from Scott Manley, as well as his tutorials for beginners. 

However, it was this series that absolutely inspired me and captured my imagination. I purchased KSP because of Manley, and I convinced 5 other people to buy the game and start playing, all because of this series. 

I recently rewatched the entire thing while recovering from surgery, and it is still fantastic. Scott, if you are reading this, I'd love to be able to buy a copy on disc or digital download or something. I'm not sure if Squad would allow that, but if so, I'd be a definite purchaser. I'd love to see some of the behind-the-scenes things like commentary on setup, builds, and editing of the clips too.

He just posted an epilogue.

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_Vu6vPytoQQ?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

> 
> I wonder if Scott Manley is going to level-up to RSS for the next series?

It looks like he might.

> 
> It looks like he might.

I hope he does. Frankly, I stopped watching his series because it was all just too easy. The increased powers of interstellar, along with the bunny slope that is the stock kerbol system, made the series more star trek than rocket program. I've been playing in RSS/64k for many months, basically since it appeared. Without that increased challenge I would have abandonded KSP long ago.

> 
> Same here. I still remember the day I watched the first episode. Oh well ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif). I'm excited for his new series.

All this talk about this series....too bad reusable space program had to end on a bad note.

it's over?

I never watched this series because it never really interested me but when I was checking Scott Manley's channel, I was alway seeing that a new video of the series was posted.

Somehow, I feel a little sad about this end, even if I never watched it.
he started this series just before i started playing ksp, and now i have been to every planet! shows you how far you can go in a series.

> 
> All this talk about this series....too bad reusable space program had to end on a bad note.

Absolutely. Interstellar was fun for the first few dozen episodes, but the mega-tech made it to much of a cakewalk. Interesting to a point, but I've no interest in playing KSP that way.

Reusable Space Program was great though. Real challenge and ingenuity, and so prescient with SpaceX's current efforts to achieve the same in real life. It inspired me to push for efficiency and economy in my designs long before career mode made that an actual advantage.

Simon Hibbs

The most impressive thing about this series was the fact that he managed to keep a heavily modded save going for so long!

My saves tend to die under the weight of multiple orbiting ships and mod-related bugs much sooner. I've had a couple that I have simply been unable to load, and have had to abandon. So props to Scott for this, helped I guess by his programming knowledge.

He did mention he would look at an RSS series, and he did mention using more LFO and less scifi stuff. I hope he does.

Actually, what I'd like to see is a reiteration of the Resusable Space Program in RSS, maybe with Karbonite or the likes... ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

PS: I really liked IQ, watched it twice over... ![:cool:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cool.gif)
That was only season 1..

> 
> That was only season 1..

That's just as bad as Firefly!

Actually while there was only 1 "season" it was over 100 episodes.

Great series. I'm still an Interstellar fan boy to this day, and loved the progression from first principles to fission engines to space folding. But all things must come to an end, and frankly, I was a bit surprised he continued the series this long. That must have been an insane effort to deal with the various modding problems that emerge in a save that big. 

Kudos you to, space man(ley)!
